pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:0.3.eng: The chapter on offenses entailing confession

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:0.5.eng: 19. The training rule on large dwellings

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.1.eng: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Kosambī in Ghosita’s Monastery,

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato channassa upaṭṭhāko mahāmatto āyasmato channassa vihāraṃ kārāpeti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.2.eng: a government official who was Venerable Channa’s supporter was making him a dwelling.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā channo katapariyositaṃ vihāraṃ punappunaṃ chādāpeti, punappunaṃ lepāpeti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.3.eng: When the dwelling was finished, Channa had it roofed and plastered over and over.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā channo tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca saṅkaḍḍhanto aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa yavakhettaṃ dūsesi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.5.eng: Then, while collecting grass and sticks, Channa spoiled the barley field belonging to a certain brahmin.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.6.pli: Atha kho so brāhmaṇo ujjhāyati khiyyati vipāceti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.6.eng: That brahmin complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.7.eng: “How can the venerables spoil my barley field?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.8.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tassa brāhmaṇassa ujjhāyantassa khiyyantassa vipācentassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.8.eng: The monks heard the complaints of that brahmin,

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.9.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.9.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized Channa,

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.10.pli: “kathañhi nāma āyasmā channo katapariyositaṃ vihāraṃ punappunaṃ chādāpessati, punappunaṃ lepāpessati, atibhārito vihāro paripatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.10.eng: “How could Venerable Channa have a finished dwelling roofed and plastered over and over until it collapsed from overloading?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.11.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ channaṃ anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.11.eng: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Channa:

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.12.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, channa, katapariyositaṃ vihāraṃ punappunaṃ chādāpesi, punappunaṃ lepāpesi, atibhārito vihāro paripatī”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.12.eng: “Is it true, Channa, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.15.pli: kathañhi nāma tvaṃ, moghapurisa, katapariyositaṃ vihāraṃ punappunaṃ chādāpessasi, punappunaṃ lepāpessasi, atibhārito vihāro paripati.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.15.eng: “Foolish man, how could you do this?

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.17.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.17.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.18.1.pli: “Mahallakaṃ pana bhikkhunā vihāraṃ kārayamānena yāva dvārakosā aggaḷaṭṭhapanāya ālokasandhiparikammāya dvatticchadanassa pariyāyaṃ appaharite ṭhitena adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ. Tato ce uttari appaharitepi ṭhito adhiṭṭhaheyya pācittiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:1.18.1.eng: ‘When a monk is building a large dwelling, then standing where there are no cultivated plants, he may apply two or three layers of roofing material, taking it as far as the doorcase and using it for fixing the door and for treating the window openings. If he applies more than that, even if he stands where there are no cultivated plants, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.2.eng: one with an owner is what is meant.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.4.pli: ullitto vā hoti avalitto vā ullittāvalitto vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.4.eng: plastered inside or plastered outside or plastered both inside and outside.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.6.eng: building it himself or having it built.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.8.eng: a distance of an arm’s reach next to the door frame.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.9.comm: Sp 3.135: Aggaḷaṭṭhapanāyāti sakavāṭakadvārabandhaṭṭhapanāya; sakavāṭakassa dvārabandhassa niccalabhāvatthāyāti attho, “Aggaḷaṭṭhapanāya: for the fixing of the doorframe together with the door panel. It is for the purpose of making the doorframe together with the door panel stable: this is the meaning.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.10.eng: for the fixing of the door.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.12.pli: vātapānaparikammāya setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.12.eng: for treating the window openings there is white color, black color, and treating with red ocher; and there is making a garland pattern, a creeper pattern, a shark-teeth pattern, and the fivefold pattern.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.12.comm: “A shark-teeth pattern” renders makaradantaka, literally, “with teeth like a makara”. In later Buddhism the makara is the name of a mythological marine animal, but what it refers to in this context is not clear. According to Sp-yoj 4.243 makara is the name of a certain species of fish: Makaradantaketi makaranāmakassa macchassa dantasadise dante, “Teeth like the teeth of a fish called makara.” Vin-vn-ṭ 3048, Makaradantakanti girikūṭākāraṁ, “Makaradantaka means making (a design) like the peak of a hill.” PED suggests “the tooth of a swordfish”, but apparently swordfish do not have teeth. Given that the makara were fearsome creatures and that their teeth looked like the peak of a hill, presumably meaning that their teeth were pointed, “shark teeth” seems like a reasonable approximation. | “The fivefold pattern” renders pañcapaṭika. Vmv 4.299: Pāḷiyaṁ pañcapaṭikanti jātiādipañcappakāravaṇṇamaṭṭhaṁ, “Pañcapaṭika in the canonical text means treated with the color of the five kinds, starting with jasmine.” The meaning is not clear. It seems unlikely, however, that it should refer to colors, since such have just been listed.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.13.eng: Standing where there are no cultivated plants, he may apply two or three layers of roofing material:

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.15.pli: Sace harite ṭhito adhiṭṭhāti, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.15.eng: if he applies it while standing where there are cultivated plants, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.16.pli: Maggena chādentassa dve magge adhiṭṭhahitvā tatiyaṃ maggaṃ āṇāpetvā pakkamitabbaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.16.eng: For someone covering by the line, after covering with two layers, he may ask for a third layer, and he should then leave.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.16.comm: “By the line” renders maggena. Sp 2.136: Aparikkhipitvā ujukameva chādanaṁ, “Not encircling, just straight covering.” As for “two layers”, dve magge, the context requires that this refers to lines on top of each other rather than next to each other. The implied purpose of “leave”, pakkamitabbaṁ, according to Sp 2.136, is to show that he may not keep on asking: Sace na pakkamati, tuṇhībhūtena ṭhātabbaṁ, “If he does not leave, he should stand in silence.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.17.pli: Pariyāyena chādentassa dve pariyāye adhiṭṭhahitvā tatiyaṃ pariyāyaṃ āṇāpetvā pakkamitabbaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.17.eng: For someone covering by the layer, after covering with two layers, he may ask for a third layer, and he should then leave.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.17.comm: Sp 3.126: Pariyāyenāti parikkhepena, “Pariyāya: by encircling.” However, since the word pariyāya is used in the sense of “layer” just before, I am assuming the meaning must be the same here.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.18.pli: Tato ce uttari appaharitepi ṭhito adhiṭṭhaheyyāti
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.18.eng: If he applies more than that, even if he stands where there are no cultivated plants:

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.19.eng: if he is covering with bricks, then for every brick, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.20.pli: Silāya chādentassa silāya silāya āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.20.eng: If he is covering with slate, then for every piece of slate, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.21.pli: Sudhāya chādentassa piṇḍe piṇḍe āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.21.eng: If he is covering with plaster, then for every lump, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.22.pli: Tiṇena chādentassa karaḷe karaḷe āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.22.eng: If he is covering with grass, then for every handful, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.23.pli: Paṇṇena chādentassa paṇṇe paṇṇe āpatti pācittiyassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.1.23.eng: If he is covering with leaves, then for every leaf, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.2.1.eng: If it is more than two or three layers, and he perceives it as more, and he applies it, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.2.2.eng: If it is more than two or three layers, but he is unsure of it, and he applies it, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.2.3.eng: If it is more than two or three layers, but he perceives it as less, and he applies it, he commits an offense entailing confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.2.4.eng: If it is less than two or three layers, but he perceives it as more, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.2.5.eng: If it is less than two or three layers, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.2.6.eng: If it is less than two or three layers, and he perceives it as less, there is no offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.3.2.eng: if he applies two or three layers;

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.3.3.eng: if he applies less than two or three layers;

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.3.5.comm: For the rendering of guhā as “cave”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.3.6.eng: if it is a grass hut;

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.3.7.eng: if it is for the benefit of someone else;

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.3.8.eng: if it is by means of his own property;

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.3.9.eng: if it is anything apart from a dwelling;

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.3.11.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pc19:2.3.12.eng: The training rule on large dwellings, the ninth, is finished.
